Entertainment.title: Cadillac Formula 1 Team Reveals Debut Livery
Entertainment.text: SummaryThe Cadillac Formula 1 Team has officially unveiled the livery for its inaugural challenger, marking its entry as the sport's 11th teamThe car features a split black and white design with a repeating chevron gradient intended to evoke speed while stationaryThe reveal took place via a national TV spot during Super Bowl LX and a simultaneous display in Times SquareThe Cadillac Formula 1 Team has formally introduced its identity to the world, pulling the covers off its first-ever race livery during a high-profile Super Bowl LX commercial break. As the grid prepares to welcome its 11th entry, the American squad bypassed the traditional paddock launch, opting instead for a dual-threat reveal at Levi's Stadium and New York City’s Times Square. The debut signals the final stretch before the team’s first on-track appearance, blending General Motors' engineering heritage with a distinctively modern aesthetic.Visually, the challenger is defined by a stark, dual-color execution. The design splits the chassis into opposing black and white sections, bridged by a gradient pattern composed of repeating Cadillac chevrons. According to the team, this motif is engineered to create a sense of motion even when the car is at a standstill, while subtly nodding to the co-ownership structure between General Motors and the racing entity.The launch strategy emphasizes the team's intent to operate at the intersection of "performance, culture, and entertainment." Dan Towriss, CEO of Cadillac Formula 1 Team Holdings, described the livery as "unmistakably American," noting that the decision to debut during the Super Bowl was a calculated move to connect with fans beyond the traditional motorsport bubble. GM President Mark Reuss framed the unveil as the culmination of a years-long effort to earn a spot on the grid, setting the stage for the team's operational debut in Melbourne. Check out the announcement details above. The Cadillac Formula 1 Team will make its competitive debut at the Australian Grand Prix, running from March 6-8 in Melbourne. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Cadillac Formula 1 Team (@cadillacf1) View this post on Instagram A post shared by Cadillac Formula 1 Team (@cadillacf1)Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast

Entertainment.title: Y-3 Channels the Athlete Within for Cinematic SS26 Campaign
Entertainment.text: SummaryThe label explores the sprawling metropolis of Los Angeles from day to nightNew footwear models like the Y-3 MEGABALL and GSG9 SANDAL are highlighted against urban backdropsA special five-piece capsule honors adidas athletes and Yohji Yamamoto himselfY-3 has officially unveiled its Spring/Summer 2026 collection campaign, taking to the streets of Los Angeles to showcase the season's latest offerings. For this seasonal narrative, the label—a collaborative effort between adidas and Yohji Yamamoto—traverses the sprawling city from day to night, utilizing locations ranging from athletic playing fields to urban alleyways.Captured by longtime collaborator Oscar Foster Kayne, the imagery juxtaposes the collection's technical construction against the dramatic L.A. landscape. The styling highlights the brand's expansive range, pairing sport-inspired jerseys with elegant tailoring. The footwear selection receives significant focus, introducing new contexts for models such as the Y-3 GSG9 SANDAL, Y-3 FIELD, Y-3 MEGABALL, and Y-3 GSG9 LO. Additional silhouettes featured include the Y-3 NIZZASTAR LO, Y-3 REGU 2002, and the Y-3 TOKYO.Beyond the main seasonal offerings, the campaign spotlights a unique five-piece capsule designed to honor the brand's connection to sport. Each item pays tribute to a specific adidas athlete associated with the number 5, including Zinedine Zidane, Jude Bellingham, Garrett Wilson, and Anthony Edwards. The hypothetical team roster is completed by a baseball jersey featuring an archival Yohji Yamamoto pattern, emblazoned with the designer's name.Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast

Entertainment.title: Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl LX Halftime Show Could Set New Record as Most-Watched Halftime Show in History
Entertainment.text: SummaryInitial reports suggested that Bad Bunny’s halftime performance set a record with over 135 million viewersNFL spokesperson Brian McCarthy clarified that no official viewership data has been authorized or released by the leagueThe official tally from Nielsen is not expected until Tuesday afternoon following the Seattle Seahawks’ victory over the New England PatriotsBad Bunny’s Super Bowl LX Halftime Show performance is looking to set a new record as the most-watched halftime show in history.Early figures report that this year’s halftime show’s reach hit a fever pitch after unofficial tallies cited a record-breaking 135.4 million viewers. This figure would place Bad Bunny at the top of the Super Bowl’s all-time viewership list, narrowly edging out Kendrick Lamar’s 133.3 million from 2025.However, the NFL has moved quickly to manage expectations, with spokesperson Brian McCarthy taking to social media to label the circulating data as "random" and confirming that nothing has been officially sanctioned by the league: "Seeing some random Super Bowl halftime and game viewership numbers floating around. Nothing has been released yet."Media insiders further reinforced this stance, noting that the standard measurement used by the league (Nielsen’s Big Data and Panel) has not yet finished processing the final count. Historically, halftime show metrics are released alongside or shortly after the overall game viewership numbers, which are typically made public on the Tuesday following the event. Until that window opens, the league remains in a holding pattern, distancing itself from the hype surrounding the alleged record.The performance itself has already become a focal point of cultural commentary, contrasting sharply with alternative broadcast events and sparking widespread discussion across social platforms. While the Seattle Seahawks secured a dominant 29-13 win on the field, the narrative surrounding Bad Bunny’s star power continues to dominate the post-game cycle.Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast

Entertainment.title: Tanjiro ‘Infinity Castle’ DLC Hits ‘Demon Slayer: Hinokami Chronicles 2’
Entertainment.text: SummaryDemon Slayer: The Hinokami Chronicles 2 adds Tanjiro Kamado in his Infinity Castle form as a new playable character DLC on February 13, 2026This marks the fourth release in the Infinity Castle Part 1 Character Pass, following Kaigaku, Zenitsu and AkazaDemon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba – The Hinokami Chronicles 2 will expand its roster with the addition of Tanjiro Kamado in his Infinity Castle form, launching as downloadable content on February 13, 2026.This version of the series' protagonist marks the fourth release in the paid "Infinity Castle Part 1 Character Pass," which introduces fighters based on the high-stakes battles featured in the first Infinity Castle film. Tanjiro follows the previous DLC releases of Kaigaku, alongside Infinity Castle versions of Zenitsu and Akaza, continuing the game's momentum of periodic post-launch updates designed to bring the movie's cinematic intensity to the VS. Mode.This version of Tanjiro introduces new fiery sword techniques and a distinctive armor set, showcased in the official trailer. The update also teases future expansions, including Giyu Tomioka later in 2026, ensuring fans can look forward to more content that mirrors the anime’s dramatic battles.The new character can be purchased individually through the Tanjiro Kamado (Infinity Castle) Character Pack or accessed as part of the Infinity Castle – Part 1 Character Pass, which also includes other fighters. Available across PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch and PC via Steam, the DLC continues the game’s tradition of adapting pivotal arcs from the anime into playable experiences.Read more at Hypebeast

Entertainment.title: Smythson and sacai Unveil Hybrid Leather Goods Collection
Entertainment.text: SummarySmythson and sacai have announced a collaboration launching on February 13, 2026The collection features three signature Smythson items—a passport cover, pouch, and Chelsea notebook—reinterpreted with sacai's hybrid aestheticDesigned by sacai Creative Director Chitose Abe, the pieces feature miniaturized briefcase handles on small leather goods, blending utility with surrealism.British luxury stationer Smythson and Japanese fashion house sacai are bridging the gap between heritage craftsmanship and avant-garde design with a new collaborative capsule. Launching on February 13, 2026, the partnership was born out of a genuine appreciation for the brand by sacai Creative Director Chitose Abe, a long-time user of Smythson’s travel accessories and diaries. The result is a collection that "layers" sacai's distinctive hybrid philosophy onto Smythson’s 130-year-old traditions, creating everyday items that feel both familiar and unexpectedly new.The collection focuses on three of Smythson's most enduring silhouettes -- the passport cover, the pouch, and the Chelsea notebook. All three are crafted from Smythson’s signature black Crossgrain Panama leather, providing a unified, classic canvas. However, the design takes a sharp turn into sacai's "disruptive" territory with the addition of miniaturized structured handles to each piece. Inspired by Smythson’s archival briefcases and luggage, these handles are repurposed on small leather goods where they serve no traditional function, creating a playful juxtaposition of scale and utility that defines Abe's design language."I feel that Smythson’s products have a quality that enriches everyday life," said Chitose Abe regarding the project. "By building on the shared philosophy at the core of both brands... I believe we were able to create a new sense of everyday." This sentiment is echoed by the collection's construction, which maintains the functional excellence Smythson is known for while transforming the items into conversation pieces. The Smythson x sacai capsule will be available starting February 13, 2026 via Smythson boutiques, sacai locations and select global retailers.Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast

Artificial Intelligence.title: New Devices Might Scale the Memory Wall
Artificial Intelligence.text: The hunt is on for anything that can surmount AI’s perennial memory wall–even quick models are bogged down by the time and energy needed to carry data between processor and memory. Resistive RAM (RRAM)could circumvent the wall by allowing computation to happen in the memory itself. Unfortunately, most types of this nonvolatile memory are too unstable and unwieldy for that purpose.Fortunately, a potential solution may be at hand. At December’s IEEE International Electron Device Meeting (IEDM), researchers from the University of California, San Diego showed they could run a learning algorithm on an entirely new type of RRAM.“We actually redesigned RRAM, completely rethinking the way it switches,” says Duygu Kuzum, an electrical engineer at the University of California, San Diego, who led the work.RRAM stores data as a level of resistance to the flow of current. The key digital operation in a neural network—multiplying arrays of numbers and then summing the results—can be done in analog simply by running current through an array of RRAM cells, connecting their outputs, and measuring the resulting current.Traditionally, RRAM stores data by creating low-resistance filaments in the higher-resistance surrounds of a dielectric material. Forming these filaments often needs voltages too high for standard CMOS, hindering its integration inside processors. Worse, forming the filaments is a noisy and random process, not ideal for storing data. (Imagine a neural network’s weights randomly drifting. Answers to the same question would change from one day to the next.) Moreover, most filament-based RRAM cells’ noisy nature means they must be isolated from their surrounding circuits, usually with a selector transistor, which makes 3D stacking difficult.Limitations like these mean that traditional RRAM isn’t great for computing. In particular, Kuzum says, it’s difficult to use filamentary RRAM for the sort of parallel matrix operations that are crucial for today’s neural networks.So, the San Diego researchers decided to dispense with the filaments entirely. Instead they developed devices that switch an entire layer from high to low resistance and back again. This format, called “bulk RRAM”, can do away with both the annoying high-voltage filament-forming step and the geometry-limiting selector transistor.3D memory for machine learningThe San Diego group wasn’t the first to build bulk RRAM devices, but it made breakthroughs both in shrinking them and forming 3D circuits with them. Kuzum and her colleagues shrank RRAM into the nanoscale; their device was just 40 nm across. They also managed to stack bulk RRAM into as many as eight layers.With a single pulse of identical voltage, an eight-layer stack of cells each of which can take any of 64 resistance values, a number that’s very difficult to achieve with traditional filamentous RRAM. And whereas the resistance of most filament-based cells are limited to kiloohms, the San Diego stack is in the megaohm range, which Kuzum says is better for parallel operations.“We can actually tune it to anywhere we want, but we think that from an integration and system-level simulations perspective, megaohm is the desirable range,” Kuzum says.These two benefits–a greater number of resistance levels and a higher resistance–could allow this bulk RRAM stack to perform more complex operations than traditional RRAM’s can manage. Kuzum and colleagues assembled multiple eight-layer stacks into a 1-kilobyte array that required no selectors. Then, they tested the array with a continual learning algorithm: making the chip classify data from wearable sensors—for example, reading data from a waist-mounted smartphone to determine if its wearer was sitting, walking, climbing stairs, or taking another action—while constantly adding new data. Tests showed an accuracy of 90 percent, which the researchers say is comparable to the performance of a digitally-implemented neural network.This test exemplifies what Kuzum thinks can especially benefit from bulk RRAM: neural network models on edge devices, which may need to learn from their environment without accessing the cloud. “We are doing a lot of characterization and material optimization to design a device specifically engineered for AI applications,” Kuzum says. The ability to integrate RRAM into an array like this is a significant advance, says Albert Talin, materials scientist at Sandia National Laboratories in Livermore, California, and a bulk RRAM researcher who wasn’t involved in the San Diego group’s work. “I think that any step in terms of integration is very useful,” he says.But Talin highlights a potential obstacle: the ability to retain data for an extended period of time. While the San Diego group showed their RRAM could retain data at room temperature for several years (on par with flash memory), Talin says that its retention at the higher temperatures where computers actually operate is less certain. “That’s one of the major challenges of this technology,” he says, especially when it comes to edge applications.If engineers can prove the technology, then all types of models may benefit. This memory wall has only grown higher this decade, as traditional memory hasn’t been able to keep up with the ballooning demands of large models. Anything that allows models to operate on the memory itself could be a welcome shortcut.

Science & Technology.title: Ferrari Officially Names First EV "Luce" and Previews Jony Ive-Designed Interior
Science & Technology.text: SummaryFerrari has confirmed its first electric vehicle will be named Luce with a full exterior reveal scheduled for MayThe interior is designed by former Apple design chief Jony Ive and Marc Newson’s creative collective LoveFromKey features include a recycled aluminum steering wheel, Corning Fusion5 glass, and a magnetized E Ink key dockFerrari has officially christened its inaugural battery-electric vehicle the Ferrari Luce, signaling a new chapter for the Maranello automaker. While the exterior remains under wraps until May, the brand has unveiled a revolutionary interior concept co-developed with Sir Jony Ive and Marc Newson of LoveFrom. This collaboration marks a significant pivot from industry trends, prioritizing tactile engagement and material excellence over the ubiquitous "screenification" of modern luxury EVs.The cabin’s architecture draws heavily from avionics and high-end horology to create an interface that is "physical and engaging." A central 12.86-inch instrument binnacle features a physical aluminum needle backed by a high-contrast OLED display, blending analogue tradition with digital precision. The three-spoke steering wheel is crafted from 100% recycled aluminum alloy and lacks any plastic components, featuring physical buttons for drive modes rather than capacitive touch surfaces.Tech-wise, the Luce introduces "Fusion5" glass developed with Corning—a material never before used in automotive applications. A 10.12-inch central screen sits on a ball-and-socket joint for adjustability, while a magnetized dock treats the key fob as a centerpiece, using E Ink to transition its color from yellow to black upon connection. Under the hood, the EV promises a "mighty" powertrain exceeding 1,000bhp, ensuring the electric transition doesn't compromise on performance. Check out the interior details above. The Ferrari Luce is scheduled for a full exterior reveal in May 2026.Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast

Science & Technology.title: Deep-coverage single-cell metabolomics enabled by ion mobility-resolved mass cytometry.
Science & Technology.text:
Paper Details
                Authors: Mingdu Luo, Tianzhang Kou, Yandong Yin, Shengyi Zhou, Xiaolan Zhu, Xinhao Zeng, Junhao Hu, Zheng-Jiang Zhu
                Institution: Interdisciplinary Research Center on Biology and Chemistry, Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, P. R. China.
                
                Journal: Nature methods
                
                Abstract
                Current single-cell metabolomics approaches are limited by insufficient sensitivity, robustness and metabolite coverage. We present an ion mobility-resolved mass cytometry technology that integrates high-throughput single-cell injection with ion mobility-mass spectrometry for multidimensional metabolomic profiling. Ion mobility-enabled selective ion accumulation and cell superposition-based amplification strategies substantially enhance sensitivity, robustness and overall analytical performance. Combined with our computational tool, MetCell, this technology allows high-throughput analysis while achieving exceptional profiling depth, detecting over 5,000 metabolic peaks and annotating approximately 800 metabolites per cell-representing a 3-fold to 10-fold improvement over existing methods. It offers attomole-level sensitivity and captures a broad dynamic range of metabolites within individual cells. Applied to 45,603 primary liver cells from aging mice, it enabled accurate cell-type and cell-subtype annotation and revealed distinct metabolic states and heterogeneity in hepatocytes during aging. This platform sets a new benchmark for high-throughput single-cell metabolomics, advancing our understanding of metabolic heterogeneity at single-cell resolution.
                
                Longevity Relevance Analysis
                The paper claims to present a novel ion mobility-resolved mass cytometry technology that significantly enhances single-cell metabolomic profiling. This research is relevant as it advances the understanding of metabolic heterogeneity in aging cells, potentially addressing root causes of aging through improved metabolic analysis.
                
                Read the full paper

Longevity & Anti-Aging.title: Reviewing What is Known of Transposon Activity in Aging
Longevity & Anti-Aging.text: Transposable elements, or transposons, are DNA sequences capable of directing the protein machinery surrounding nuclear DNA to haphazardly insert copies of the transposon elsewhere in the genome, potentially breaking other necessary sequences. Transposons are thought to be the remnants of ancient viral infections, but given that transposon activities are most likely an important mechanism of evolution, driving functional changes that can then be selected, that may not be universally true. Transposons are suppressed in youth, the structure of DNA managed by epigenetic mechanisms to package away transposon sequences into heterochromatin structures and thus hide them from transcription machinery in the cell nucleus. With advancing age the epigenetic control of DNA structure changes in a variety of ways, altering the expression of many genes to contribute […]

Longevity & Anti-Aging.title: tRNA Synthetase Inhibitors Improve Autophagy to Slow Aging
Longevity & Anti-Aging.text: Most of the approaches demonstrated to alter metabolism in ways that modestly slow aging and extend life involve an increased efficiency of autophagy. This includes mild stresses resulting from exercise, calorie restriction, heat, cold, and low levels of toxin exposure. The processes of autophagy act to recycle damaged or otherwise unwanted cellular components into amino acids that can be used for further protein synthesis, improving cell function. Thus there is interest in the scientific community in finding drugs that can induce increased autophagy. The best known, most readily available, and most advanced in the clinic are varieties of mTOR inhibitor, rapamycin being the canonical example. But many other classes of small molecule may prove to be interesting enough to develop into drugs. Macroautophagy, henceforth referred […]

Longevity & Anti-Aging.title: Adoptive Natural Killer Cell Therapy to Destroy Senescent Cells
Longevity & Anti-Aging.text: Cell therapies seem the least likely of approaches to make it into the clinic as a treatment to selectively destroy the senescent cells that linger to cause harm in aged tissues. While it is a very plausible goal to take a CAR T cell therapy and target it to senescent cells, or use adoptive transfer of other immune cell types known to attack senescent cells, as these are just variations on strategies already well demonstrated to work in other contexts, the cost and logistical effort is enormous in comparison to other approaches to the selective destruction of senescence cells. It is far more likely that therapies to adjust the operation of native immune cells, such as the approach under development by Deciduous Therapeutics, or forms […]

Longevity & Anti-Aging.title: Telomeres and Telomerase.
Longevity & Anti-Aging.text:
Paper Details
                Authors: Julia Promisel Cooper, Eros Lazzerini Denchi, Joachim Lingner, Hilda A Pickett
                Institution: Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics, University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, Aurora, Colorado 80045, USA julia.p.cooper@cuanschutz.edu eros.lazzerinidenchi@nih.gov joachim.lingner@epfl.ch hpickett@cmri.org.au.
                
                Journal: Cold Spring Harbor perspectives in biology
                
                Abstract
                Telomeres represent a molecular nexus where genome stability, aging, disease susceptibility, and regenerative potential converge. Advances in understanding how telomeres are replicated, protected, and repaired now inform fundamental questions about human lifespan, tissue renewal, the molecular origins of age-related decline, and cancer evolution. This volume presents an integrated collection of perspectives spanning telomere architecture, replication dynamics, telomere-driven genome instability, and telomere maintenance by telomerase and Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT), while also charting new therapeutic directions grounded in telomere biology. Drawing on molecular, structural, organismal, and clinical research, this collection showcases a field in rapid motion, reshaping our view of regeneration, aging, and disease.
                
                Longevity Relevance Analysis
                The paper discusses the role of telomeres and telomerase in aging and genome stability, suggesting that understanding these mechanisms can inform approaches to lifespan extension and age-related decline. The focus on telomere biology and its implications for regeneration and aging makes it relevant to longevity research.
